perturbation.original_text: 16.01 Investor at any time may provide written notice to Company of a material breach of this IP Agreement. If Company fails to cure the identified breach within thirty (30) days after the date of the notice, Investor may terminate this IP Agreement by written notice to Company.
perturbation.changed_text: 16.01 Investor at any time may provide written notice to Company of a material breach of this IP Agreement. If Company fails to cure the identified breach within sixty (60) days after the date of the notice, Investor may terminate this IP Agreement by written notice to Company.
perturbation.explanation: The change introduces a contradiction regarding the cure period for a material breach. Originally, the Company had 30 days to cure a breach. The modified text extends this period to 60 days, creating uncertainty about the applicable cure period and potentially leading to disputes over the termination rights.

perturbation.original_text: 18.03 Litigation or Arbitration as a Final Resort. If the Parties cannot resolve any Dispute for any reason, including, but not limited to, the failure of the Parties to agree to enter into mediation or agree to any settlement proposed by the mediator, within sixty (60) days after the Escalation to Mediation Date, either the Company or the Holder may file suit in a court of competent jurisdiction in accordance with Article 18.04.
perturbation.changed_text: 18.03 Litigation or Arbitration as a Final Resort. If the Parties cannot resolve any Dispute for any reason, including, but not limited to, the failure of the Parties to agree to enter into mediation or agree to any settlement proposed by the mediator, within thirty (30) days after the Escalation to Mediation Date, either the Company or the Holder may file suit in a court of competent jurisdiction in accordance with Article 18.04.
perturbation.explanation: Here, the time frame to enter into litigation is changed from 60 to 30 days after the Escalation to Mediation Date, creating another contradiction with article 18.01, where mediation is supposed to occur, but this may also be undermined.

perturbation.original_text: 8.00 This IP Agreement imposes personal obligations on Investor. Investor will not assign to any Third Party any rights under this IP Agreement not specifically transferable by its terms without the prior written consent of Company, such consent not to be unreasonably withheld. For the avoidance of doubt and notwithstanding the foregoing: (1) such rights are assignable by Investor to an Affiliate of Investor, and (2) Investor's rights in Investor Improvements and Joint Improvements shall be freely assignable by Investor to any Person.
perturbation.changed_text: 8.00 This IP Agreement imposes personal obligations on Investor. Investor will not assign to any Third Party any rights under this IP Agreement not specifically transferable by its terms without the prior written consent of Company, such consent may be withheld at Company's sole discretion. For the avoidance of doubt and notwithstanding the foregoing: (1) such rights are assignable by Investor to an Affiliate of Investor, and (2) Investor's rights in Investor Improvements and Joint Improvements shall only be assignable by Investor with written consent from the Company.
perturbation.explanation: The change makes the consent from Company discretionary, and investor improvements are no longer freely assignable without consent of the company. This contradicts with the original text, which makes it freely assignable and Company needs to be reasonable to give consent, and this may lead to disputes.
